document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy and molecular phylogeny of four karyorelictid species belonging to the genera Apotrachelocerca and Tracheloraphis (Protozoa: Ciliophora), with descriptions of two new species

subSubSection.paragraph: Z o o b a n k r e g i s t r a t i o n: u r n: l s i d: z o o b a n k. o r g: a c t: A 8 2 B 3 8 9 9 - B E D 2 - 4 1 6 0 - 8 0 D 4 - 3718F962CE8B

Diagnosis: Body length in vivo 200–500 Μm; single nuclear group composed of two or three macronuclei and one micronucleus; six to seven somatic kineties on right side, left side unciliated except for bristle kinety; spine-like cilia on border of glabrous stripe; width of glabrous stripe same as trunk; no cortical granules.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 3.
Apotrachelocerca orientalis
sp. nov. from life (A–E) and after protargol staining (F–I). A, a representative individual. B, C, two different extremely contracted cells. D, variation in composition of the nuclear group. E, middle region of slightly contracted cell showing ellipsoidal inclusions and the rugged edge, arrows mark the bristle cilia. F, G, infraciliature of right (F) and left (G) side of the holotype specimen, showing left side almost completely occupied by the glabrous stripe and absence of secant system. H, I, right (H) and left (I) side view of anterior body region, showing glabrous stripe, somatic kineties, bristle kinety, and continuous (uninterrupted) circumoral kineties consisting of two rows of dikinetids. Abbreviations: BK, bristle kinety; CK, circumoral kineties; GS, glabrous stripe; Ma, macronuclei; Mi, micronucleus; N, nuclear group. Scale bars: 150 Μm (A); 100 Μm (B–C); 50 Μm (F–G).

Figure 4. Photomicrographs of
Apotrachelocerca orientalis
sp. nov. from life (A–H) and after protargol staining (I–O). A, B, typical individuals. C, D, views of different extremely contracted cells. E, detail of middle region marking the rugged edge (arrow) and the spine-like bristle cilia (arrowheads). F, G, anterior region and tail, arrows mark the endoplasmic inclusions. H, ellipsoidal inclusions and globular granules (red arrows). I, right side view of mid-region of cell. J, K, detail of nuclear groups. K, showing nuclear group by the invertible function of Photoshop. L, M, infraciliature of right (L) and left (M) side of the holotype specimen. N, right side view of anterior body region, indicating somatic kineties (arrow) and circumoral kineties (arrowhead). O, left side view of anterior body region, showing bristle kinety (arrow) and circumoral kineties (arrowhead). Abbreviations: Ma, macronuclei. Scale bars: 150 Μm (A–B); 100 Μm (C–D); 50 Μm (L–M).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality:
The intertidal zone of a swimming beach near the Zhanqiao Pier in Qingdao ( 36°03′50″N , 120°19′47″E ), China
.
Type specimens: A protargol slide containing the holotype specimen marked with an ink circle is deposited in the Laboratory of Protozoology, OUC (No. MMZ2018122201).

Etymology: The species-group name
orientalis – from
Latin oriens , east – reflects that this organism was first discovered in east China .

Description: Fully extended cells about 400 × 15 Μm in vivo ; body flexible and dorsoventrally flattened, i.e. ribbon-like ( Figs 3A , 4A, B ). Body width almost constant in anterior three-quarters of cell, with no distinguishable neck region; posterior quarter progressively narrowed forming a curved tail. Cytoplasm colourless and transparent under high magnification, but appears to be yellow-greenish or brownish at lower magnifications, possibly due to food

caption.paragraph:
Table 3. Morphometric data for
Apotrachelocerca orientalis
sp. nov. (first line),
Tracheloraphis prenanti
(second line),
T. oligostriata
(third line) and
T. apoligostriata
sp. nov. (fourth line)

subSubSection.paragraph: contents and/or colourless to dark brownish inclusions (mitochondria?), about 2–3 Μm in size, ellipsoid in shape and located beneath pellicle ( Figs 3E , 4D, E, F, G ). Pellicle thin and characteristically forming a nipple-like rugged edge in contracted cells ( Fig. 4E ). Cortical granules not recognized. Single nuclear group located in centre of trunk, containing two or three (usually two) macronuclei, 4–6 Μm in diameter and, invariably, one micronucleus located between macronuclei ( Figs 3D, G , 4J, K, M ). Somatic cilia about 10 Μm long; bristle cilia rigid, spine-like and readily observable in vivo ( Fig. 4E ). Locomotion by gliding between sand grains and organic debris.

Infraciliature consisting of dikinetids on right side. Glabrous stripe occuping entire left side; right side with six to seven somatic kineties, cilia c . 10 Μm long ( Figs 3F–I , 4L–O ). No anterior or posterior secant system ( Figs 3G, I , 4M, O ). Glabrous stripe bordered by one bristle kinety composed of dikinetids; only one basal body of each dikinetid bearing a cilium ( Fig. 3E ). Circumoral kineties composed of two uninterrupted rows of dikinetids; upper row winding anticlockwise, lower row winding clockwise ( Figs 3H, I , 4N, O ).
